Award.AwardTitle: Support to Broaden Student Participation in the 2021 Meeting of the North American Membrane Society (NAMS)

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: This award will provide travel support for 13 U.S.-based undergraduate students to attend the 2021 Meeting of the North American Membrane Society (NAMS) at Estes Park, Colorado. NAMS is a premier membrane conference, providing outstanding technical sessions across the full breadth of topics within membrane science and technology. The theme of the 2021 meeting is "Convergence - Connecting Membrane Science to Societal Challenges," which aligns with several Grand Challenges recently identified by the National Academy of Engineering. The meeting has a rich history of engaging graduate student researchers directly through targeted programs and award opportunities. The goal of this travel support is to extend these opportunities to undergraduate researchers who identify as a member of an underrepresented group in STEM and might otherwise be unable to attend the conference. Additionally, it will provide a platform for students to network with community leaders and fellow undergraduate and graduate students. A unique undergraduate mentoring program will foster inclusivity and encourage the students to take full advantage of the technical, social, and networking opportunities available at NAMS 2021. Early engagement in a professional society/conference will provide students with motivation and encouragement to pursue advanced degrees in their respective fields and, subsequently, develop a healthy and diverse workforce.<br/><br/>The NAMS organizing committee is comprised of diverse North American researchers, and invited speakers from academia, industry, and government labs feature prominently in the program. The meeting will feature 26 technical sessions, daily plenary sessions, a poster session, and abundant unstructured discussion periods to catalyze new collaborative relationships and research ideas. The 2021 NAMS meeting will cover a variety of topics ranging from fundamental studies of membrane material science to process systems development and applications of membrane technology in water, bioprocessing, chemical separations, environmental systems, and energy. Historically, hundreds of graduate students participate in the NAMS meeting and engage in unique professional development and training opportunities. This award will extend such opportunities to a cohort of U.S. undergraduate students with the intention of growing and retaining a diverse community of membrane scientists and engineers. All undergraduate attendees will be paired with senior graduate student mentors who will serve as meeting guides and support an immersive experience. The program's effectiveness will be assessed through surveys and observation of student outcomes. It is anticipated that the award for travel and registration fee subsidies will attract diverse young scientists in the field and enhance the membrane science and technology workforce.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

The main objective of this award was to provide travel support for graduate students and postdocs, especially female and underrepresented minority (URM) students, to attend the 30th North American Membrane Society (NAMS) conference in-person in Estes Park, CO (Aug. 28th ? Sep. 2nd, 2021).  NAMS is the premier conference in the field of membrane science and technology. The theme of the 30th NAMS conference was "Convergence: Connecting Membrane Science with Society Challenges".

Overall, the conference offered 160 oral presentations and 110 posters.  The technical and intellectual contents of the conference were outstanding, featuring,

  • Three plenary talks on biomedical and tissue engineering (Prof. Kristi Anseth), renewable energy (Dr. Peter Green) and bio-and artificial membranes (Prof. Thomas Schafer).
  • Four "convergence" themed special sessions, all with mixed industrial and academic experts, in Pharmaceutical Processing, Environmental Applications, Medicine and Public Heath, and Energy and Chemical Processing.
  • Three debate sessions on the topics of, "New Materials Science and Commercialization", "Is Water Public or Private Goods", and "Funding the Gap between Academic Discoveries and Translation to Application".
  • A special session of "Alan S. Michaels Award Recipients on Convergence". ASM award is the highest award given to membrane researchers (one awardee every three years). Six out of the Seven total awardees presented their perspectives on membrane-based biopharmaceutical manufacturing (Andrew Zydney), fluoropolymers in separation (Kam Sirkar), status of synthetic membranes (Georges Belfort), water treatment (Norman Li), new materials for membrane applications (Bill Koros), and CO2 capture with membranes (Richard Baker).
  • Thirty technical sessions covered all aspects of membrane science and technology.

As one of the earliest in-person conferences (the earliest for membrane conference) since pandemic, the conference received 352 abstracts and 260 in-person attendees. The pandemic shutdown presented tremendous challenges for professional development of graduate students and postdoc researchers, who typically have 2 to 5 years of training and education. Recognized this challenge, the conference co-chairs, with the support of NAMS board of directors, worked hard to make the NAMS 2021 a much-needed professional development and networking opportunity for the students and postdoc researchers.  Among the 260 attendees, half of them are graduate students and postdocs, while the other half attendees are a good mix of senior researchers from academia and industry, with additional several attendees from national labs.  Besides the technical sessions mentioned above, the conference provided a series of events to maximize the networking opportunity, including,

  • Two poster sessions maximized the networking time/opportunity for the attendees.
  • Lunch with Legends: all student/postdoc attendees were invited to have lunch with senior membrane researchers for networking.
  • Tuesday afternoon group hikes in Estes Park.
  • Conference banquet for award recognition and celebration. 

 

This NSF award supported 22 graduate students and 3 postdoc researchers attend the meeting in-person.  Among them, 18 were female and 12 were with URM background.  Their participation in the conference greatly enhanced the diversity of the meeting.  The awardees were from New Mexico State University, University of Arizona, University of Colorado, University of Arizona, University of Houston, University of Arkansas, University of Alabama, University of Kentucky, University of Tennessee, Penn State University, and Lawrence Berkeley National Lab (lab shutdown, the two postdocs were attending the meeting on their own expenses).  The NSF award was leveraged with NAMS Elias Klein Travel supplement award (supporting 17 graduate students) and NAMS student fellowship award (supporting 3 students). The students supported by this award all participated in the poster competition, and won 4 of the 8 poster awards, as listed below: 

  • Rollie G Mills (University of Kentucky), "Advancing Microporous Membranes for Mask and Filter Applications Towards Aerosol Capture and Coronavirus Deactivation". (2nd place in Session A: Fundamentals, Emerging Materials, and Process)
  • Zachary Binger (University of Arizona), "A Solution-diffusion with defects model to explain pressure-dependent membrane permeability in pressure retarded osmosis". (2nd place in Session B: Water, Energy and the Nexus)
  • Kaitlyn P Brickey (Pennsylvania State University), "Elucidating the structure-performance relationship in commercially relevant virus filters using 3D electron tomography". (1st place in Session D: Innovation in membrane materials, synthesis and characterization: Liquids)
  • Francisco Leniz (University of Kentucky), "Organic anions nanofiltration with application to perfluoro organics". (2nd place in Session D: Innovation in membrane materials, synthesis and characterization: Liquids)
